elements.content: Six new anionic bismuth-oxido clusters containing trifluoroacetate ligands were prepared. These include two new Bi6O8 clusters: [M­(NCMe)2(H2O)4]3[Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(CF3CO2)12] with an octahedral Bi6O4(OH)4 core (M = Ni, 1a; Co, 1b) and four Bi4O2 clusters, {[Co­(NCMe)6]­[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]} n (2a), {[Co­{HC­(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]­[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]·2­[CF3CO2]·2­[CF3CO2H]·2­[H2O]} n (2b), {[Cu­(NCMe)4]2[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]·2­[CF3CO2H]} n (2c), and {[Me4N]2[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]·2­[CF3CO2H]} n (2d). These are among the first bismuth-oxido anionic clusters synthesized, and the first to have transition metal countercations. The Bi6O8 anion in 1a and 1b is a high-symmetry octahedron. Additionally, two of the new Bi4O2 clusters are arranged in 1D polymeric structures via bridging carboxylate ligands. The cation in compound 2c had not been previously characterized and was also observed in the synthesis of [Co­{HC­(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]­[Bi­(NO3)6] (3). The new compounds were characterized using single crystal X-ray crystallography and elemental analysis.

These are among the first bismuth-oxido anionic clusters synthesized, and the first to have transition metal countercations. The Bi6O8 anion in 1a and 1b is a high-symmetry octahedron. Additionally, two of the new Bi4O2 clusters are arranged in 1D polymeric structures via bridging carboxylate ligands. The cation in compound 2c had not been previously characterized and was also observed in the synthesis of [Co{HC(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2][Bi(NO3)6] (3). The new compounds were characterized using single crystal X-ray crystallography and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Anionic bismuth oxido carboxylates are produced readily from BiPh3 and trifluoroacetic acid in the presence of metal complexes that can serve as the source of ML n x+ countercations. These cations stabilize the addition of trifluoroacetate anions to neutral bismuth oxido carboxylate cores. In this fashion, the new anions have been prepared: [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(CF3CO2)12]6− and {[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]2−} n . The new cation [Co­{(MeC)3CH­(NH)­O2}2]3+ was created by coupling Co­(acac)3 and MeCN, and a previously unreported hexanitrato complex of bismuth, [Co­{(MeC)3CH­(NH)­O2}2]­[Bi­(NO3)6], was characterized.
elements.clean_text: Anionic bismuth oxido carboxylates are produced readily from BiPh3 and trifluoroacetic acid in the presence of metal complexes that can serve as the source of ML n   x+ countercations. These cations stabilize the addition of trifluoroacetate anions to neutral bismuth oxido carboxylate cores. In this fashion, the new anions have been prepared: [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(CF3CO2)12]6- and {[Bi4(μ3-O)2(CF3CO2)10]2-} n . The new cation [Co{(MeC)3CH(NH)O2}2]3+ was created by coupling Co(acac)3 and MeCN, and a previously unreported hexanitrato complex of bismuth, [Co{(MeC)3CH(NH)O2}2][Bi(NO3)6], was characterized.

elements.content: Bismuth is a useful component of many drugs with potential for diverse chemical and biological applications. Its unique properties along with its nontoxicity has led bismuth to be utilized in alloys, nontoxic pigments, thermoelectric and ferroelectric materials, and catalysts. Bismuth-oxido clusters have drawn attention from several groups, as they highlight bismuth’s ability to form large, multinuclear oxido complexes. These clusters are readily synthesized via hydrolysis of the bismuth­(III) compounds and can be used as precursors for bismuth-based solid state materials applications.
elements.clean_text: Bismuth is a useful component of many drugs with potential for diverse chemical and biological applications. Its unique properties along with its nontoxicity has led bismuth to be utilized in alloys, nontoxic pigments, thermoelectric and ferroelectric materials, and catalysts. Bismuth-oxido clusters have drawn attention from several groups, as they highlight bismuth's ability to form large, multinuclear oxido complexes. These clusters are readily synthesized via hydrolysis of the bismuth(III) compounds and can be used as precursors for bismuth-based solid state materials applications.

elements.content: Bismuth compounds have long been known to undergo hydrolysis. The halides, such as BiCl3, readily form the subhalides BiOX upon treatment with water, although hydrated intermediates have been observed. The products of the hydrolysis of bismuth nitrate and perchlorate have been studied crystallographically and show the formation of discrete oxido cluster species. Complexes with salicylate (H2sal = HO-2-C6H4CO2H) were particularly of interest owing to the known biological activity of bismuth subsalicylate. Among the nuclearities observed for that ligand alone are [Bi4(μ3-O)2(Hsal)8]·2Solv (Solv = MeCN or MeNO2), [Bi9O7(Hsal)13(Me2CO)1.5]·(Me2CO)1.5, [Bi22O24(Hsal)14], [Bi38O45(Hsal)22(OH)2(DMSO)16.5]·DMSO-·H2O, and [Bi38O44(Hsal)26(Me2CO)16(H2O)2]·(Me2CO)4. Oxido-clusters supported by alkoxides, other carboxylates, and hexafluoroacetylacetonate have also been reported. They contain a core composed of Bi­(III) and oxygen atoms that has an overall positive charge. These cores are then surrounded by negatively charged carboxylate ligands to form an overall neutral compound. A common structural motif in these systems is the observation of the octahedral Bi6O8 2+ core in which oxide ions (or hydroxide) adopt μ3 bridging configurations on each of the octahedral faces. The same octahedral component is found as a subunit in the larger bismuth alkoxide and carboxylate structures. For the latter, a variety of nuclearities have been observed.

elements.content: Negatively charged bismuth-oxido carboxylate clusters on the other hand are rare. The [{Bi38O45­(C4H7SO3)8­(NO3)14­(dmso)19.5(H2O)2}]2+ cation is found paired with the anionic cluster [{Bi38O45­(C4H7SO3)10­(NO3)16­(dmso)16(H2O)2}]2–. The reaction of Bi­(O3SCF3) with organodichalcogenones has produced [Bi­(1,1′-methylenebis­(3-methyl-1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazole-2-thione)6]3+ paired with [Bi6(OH)8(O3SCF3)12]3–.

elements.content: The products of the reaction of bismuth trifluoroacetate hydrolysis in aqueous solutions and thermolysis in arene solvents have been reported by Kugel. He observed the formation of the unit Bi3O­(O2CCF3)7 ligated by arenes both in monomeric and dimeric forms, but he also characterized Bi6O8 n+ species in [Bi6O5(OH)3(H2O)2(O2CCF3)2]2[Bi­(O2CCF3)5]3·4H2O and [Bi6O4(OH)4]­[Bi10O8(O2CCF3)20]. In the latter compound, the­[Bi10O8(O2CCF3)20]6– ion is described as a Bi6O8 2+ cluster coordinated to four [Bi­(O2CCF3)5]2– fragments.

He observed the formation of the unit Bi3O(O2CCF3)7 ligated by arenes both in monomeric and dimeric forms, but he also characterized Bi6O8  n+ species in [Bi6O5(OH)3(H2O)2(O2CCF3)2]2[Bi(O2CCF3)5]3⋅4H2O and [Bi6O4(OH)4][Bi10O8(O2CCF3)20]. In the latter compound, the[Bi10O8(O2CCF3)20]6- ion is described as a Bi6O8 2+ cluster coordinated to four [Bi(O2CCF3)5]2- fragments.

elements.content: In continuation of our previous studies on bismuth carboxylates formed by the reaction of BiPh3 and carboxylic acids, we have examined reactions with trifluoroacetic acid. Performing reactions similar to those previously reported but in the presence of a metal cation source, the synthesis and structure of six new anionic bismuth-oxido clusters with trifluoroacetate ligands are described. Our initial motivation was to create heterobimetallic complexes in situ by the formation of Bi­(O2CR)3 in the presence of M­(acac)3 complexes based on our prior observations of coordination of M­(acac)3 to the bismuth carboxylates. We discovered, however, that under these conditions the M­(acac)3 are not stable and provide a templating metal counterion that systematically promotes the formation of anionic bismuth oxido carboxylates. Use of other non-acac metal complexes as well as organic counterions has also proven effective for the production of these complexes. Herein, we report the formation of two salts of [Bi6O4(OH)4(O2CCF3)12]6– and four complexes containing polymeric {[Bi4O2(O2CCF3)10]2–} n anions.

Performing reactions similar to those previously reported but in the presence of a metal cation source, the synthesis and structure of six new anionic bismuth-oxido clusters with trifluoroacetate ligands are described. Our initial motivation was to create heterobimetallic complexes in situ by the formation of Bi(O2CR)3 in the presence of M(acac)3 complexes based on our prior observations of coordination of M(acac)3 to the bismuth carboxylates. We discovered, however, that under these conditions the M(acac)3 are not stable and provide a templating metal counterion that systematically promotes the formation of anionic bismuth oxido carboxylates. Use of other non-acac metal complexes as well as organic counterions has also proven effective for the production of these complexes. Herein, we report the formation of two salts of [Bi6O4(OH)4(O2CCF3)12]6- and four complexes containing polymeric {[Bi4O2(O2CCF3)10]2-} n  anions.

elements.content: A number of years ago, we developed the solvolysis of BiPh3 by acidic alcohols and carboxylic acids to produce cleanly Bi­(OR)3 and Bi­(O2CR)3 derivatives. This provided a convenient facile and high yield route that avoided complications using traditional salt metathesis methods. The complexes so produced proved to be sensitive to hydrolysis, and a variety of bismuth oxido clusters were obtained as a result. Andrews developed this methodology to produce Bi9 and Bi38 oxido salicylate clusters. More recently, we have turned to examining trifluoroacetate as an oxidatively stable ligand for preparation of bismuth oxido compounds. Earlier work on hydrolysis and decomposition of bismuth trifluoroacetate in aqueous and arene solvents has been reported in the thesis of Kugel. We had observed earlier that metal acac complexes can form complexes with Bi­(Hsal)3 and decided to explore the synthesis of bismuth carboxylates in the presence of various metal acac complexes as a direct route to heterometallic compounds. Simple addition of the acac complexes did not occur in this case. Rather, acid promoted conversion of the metal acac species into other metal cations was observed with the unexpected consequence that the presence of these metal cations in solution gave rise to new anionic bismuth oxido clusters where the transition metal served as a simple counterion. On the basis of that observation, a variety of other metal complexes were used to explore the generality of the reaction. Organic cations may also be used. Depending on conditions, either the octahedral [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3–OH)4(tfa)12]6– (tfa– = CF3CO2 –) or essentially planar [Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa) x ]2– (x = 9, 10) species were obtained. gives an overview of the different conditions used to synthesize these new bismuth-oxido clusters with transition metal cations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

A number of years ago, we developed the solvolysis of BiPh3 by acidic alcohols and carboxylic acids to produce cleanly Bi(OR)3 and Bi(O2CR)3 derivatives. This provided a convenient facile and high yield route that avoided complications using traditional salt metathesis methods. The complexes so produced proved to be sensitive to hydrolysis, and a variety of bismuth oxido clusters were obtained as a result. Andrews developed this methodology to produce Bi9 and Bi38 oxido salicylate clusters. More recently, we have turned to examining trifluoroacetate as an oxidatively stable ligand for preparation of bismuth oxido compounds. Earlier work on hydrolysis and decomposition of bismuth trifluoroacetate in aqueous and arene solvents has been reported in the thesis of Kugel. We had observed earlier that metal acac complexes can form complexes with Bi(Hsal)3  and decided to explore the synthesis of bismuth carboxylates in the presence of various metal acac complexes as a direct route to heterometallic compounds. Simple addition of the acac complexes did not occur in this case. Rather, acid promoted conversion of the metal acac species into other metal cations was observed with the unexpected consequence that the presence of these metal cations in solution gave rise to new anionic bismuth oxido clusters where the transition metal served as a simple counterion. On the basis of that observation, a variety of other metal complexes were used to explore the generality of the reaction. Organic cations may also be used. Depending on conditions, either the octahedral [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(tfa)12]6- (tfa- = CF3CO2 -) or essentially planar [Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa) x ]2- (x = 9, 10) species were obtained.  gives an overview of the different conditions used to synthesize these new bismuth-oxido clusters with transition metal cations.

Summary of Synthesis of Anionic Bismuth-Oxido Clusters Using Transition Metal Countercations<xref rid="tbl1-fn1"></xref> compound solvent used transition metal source cation synthesized anion synthesized 1a MeCN Ni(II) formate [Ni(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ [Bi6O4(OH)4(CF3CO2)12]6– 1b MeCN Co(II) acetate [Co(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ [Bi6O4(OH)4(CF3CO2)12]6– 2a MeCN/toluene Co(III) acac [Co(NCMe)6]2+ [Bi4O2(CF3CO2)10]2– 2b MeCN Co(III) acac [Co{HC(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]3+ [Bi4O2(CF3CO2)10]2– 2c MeCN Cu(I) oxide [Cu(NCMe)4]+ [Bi4O2(CF3CO2)10]2–

Triphenylbismuth and trifluoroacetic acid were also reactants for all reactions.

The compounds 1a and 1b were synthesized by dissolving BiPh3 in acetonitrile (MeCN) followed by the addition of trifluoroacetic acid and either nickel­(II) formate or cobalt­(II) acetate tetrahydrate. The complexes crystallized from solution upon standing, but the nickel reaction has proven more difficult to reproduce, unlike the cobalt reaction that always worked well. The new highly symmetrical anionic bismuth-oxido cluster anion [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(tfa)12]6– crystallized as either the [Ni­(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ (1a) or [Co­(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ (1b) salts under these conditions. The cation [Ni­(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ has been reported once previously, as known of both the cations and anions (, ). There are three ML n 2+ cations per oxido cluster, requiring that the overall charge on the cluster be +6. This is only achieved if there are equal numbers of O2– and OH– ligands, giving the formula of the anion as [Bi6O4(OH)4(tfa)12]6–. The H2O and MeCN ligands of the cation are disordered over two positions. The fundamental solvolysis process can be written as shown in . 6 BiPh 3 + 6 CF 3 CO 2 H + 6 CF 3 CO 2 − + 8 H 2 O → [ Bi 6 O 4 ( OH ) 4 ( CF 3 CO 2 ) 12 ] 6 − + 18 Ph − H

Octahedral [M(NCMe)2(H2O)4]3[Bi6O4(OH)4(tfa)12] (M = Ni, Co)

The compounds 1a and 1b were synthesized by dissolving BiPh3 in acetonitrile (MeCN) followed by the addition of trifluoroacetic acid and either nickel(II) formate or cobalt(II) acetate tetrahydrate. The complexes crystallized from solution upon standing, but the nickel reaction has proven more difficult to reproduce, unlike the cobalt reaction that always worked well. The new highly symmetrical anionic bismuth-oxido cluster anion [Bi6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(tfa)12]6- crystallized as either the [Ni(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ (1a) or [Co(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ (1b) salts under these conditions. The cation [Ni(NCMe)2(H2O)4]2+ has been reported once previously, as known of both the cations and anions (, ). There are three ML n  2+ cations per oxido cluster, requiring that the overall charge on the cluster be +6. This is only achieved if there are equal numbers of O2- and OH- ligands, giving the formula of the anion as [Bi6O4(OH)4(tfa)12]6-. The H2O and MeCN ligands of the cation are disordered over two positions. The fundamental solvolysis process can be written as shown in . 1        6   BiPh   3   + 6   CF   3     CO   2   H + 6   CF   3       CO   2     -   + 8   H   2   O →        [   Bi   6     O   4     ( OH )   4     (   CF   3     CO   2   )   12   ]    6 -   + 18 Ph - H

The Bi6O4(OH)4 6+ core is highly symmetric, with the four oxide and four hydroxide ligands being refined in a statistically disordered model over the eight faces of the Bi6 octahedron as required by the crystallographic Oh site symmetry. This is essentially a superposition of two orientations of the molecules with rigorous Td symmetry as shown in 1, consistent with prior reports of similar Bi6 oxido cations (). In this disorder model, each face of the Bi6 octahedron is bridged by a 1:1 ratio of O to OH that were each refined at half occupancy resulting from the imposition of a crystallographic inversion center in the centroid of the Bi6 octahedron of 1. The trifluoroacetate ligands symmetrically bridge each Bi–Bi vector, making the bismuth atoms overall 8-coordinate. The octahedral Bi6O8–x (OH) x n+ core is well-known. Previously reported examples are given in . The cationic species have a variety of interactions with the corresponding anions that stabilize the central highly symmetrical oxido cluster. The anionic species synthesized have slightly shorter Bi–O bond lengths than most of the known neutral or cationic species.

cit = citrate.

A new series of anionic compounds containing the Bi4(μ3-O)2 core with 10 trifluoracetate ligands and various cations were characterized, and a summary of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters is provided in . These syntheses were easily reproducible. The methodology was essentially the same as that leading to the octahedral Bi oxido compounds 1a and 1b. The cations included [Co­(NCMe)6]2+ (2a), [Co­{HC­(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]3+ (2b), [Cu­(NCMe)4]+ (2c), and Me4N+ (2d) cations for {[Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa)10]2–} n . While it was originally intended that the metal ions would be incorporated into the bismuth oxido cluster framework, the presence of the metal ions provides a means of conceptually adding [ML n ]­[O2CCF3] x to the neutral [Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa)8], a compound which has not been previously reported but is known for several other carboxylates.
elements.clean_text:
Anionic Bi4(μ3-O)2 Compounds

A new series of anionic compounds containing the Bi4(μ3-O)2 core with 10 trifluoracetate ligands and various cations were characterized, and a summary of the crystallographic data collection and refinement parameters is provided in . These syntheses were easily reproducible. The methodology was essentially the same as that leading to the octahedral Bi oxido compounds 1a and 1b. The cations included [Co(NCMe)6]2+ (2a), [Co{HC(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]3+ (2b), [Cu(NCMe)4]+ (2c), and Me4N+ (2d) cations for {[Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa)10]2-} n . While it was originally intended that the metal ions would be incorporated into the bismuth oxido cluster framework, the presence of the metal ions provides a means of conceptually adding [ML n ][O2CCF3] x  to the neutral [Bi4(μ3-O)2(tfa)8], a compound which has not been previously reported but is known for several other carboxylates.

Compounds 2a and 2b were synthesized using cobalt­(III) acac in reaction with BiPh3 and trifluoroacetic acid in acetonitrile. The reaction mixture for 2a was then layered over toluene while the mixture for 2b was not. While both reactions resulted in the synthesis of similar polymeric anionic clusters, the cations in the crystal lattice differed greatly, as 2b contains a cation with tripodal ligands not previously reported which participates in a hydrogen bonded network. The structure also contains free trifluoroacetic acid in the lattice. The anion in 2a is balanced by a hexakis­(acetonitrile)­cobalt­(III) cation. Additionally, the asymmetric unit of the anion of 2a forms a 1-D polymer bridged by two trifluoroacetate ligands between two adjacent cluster units (b).

The structure also contains free trifluoroacetic acid in the lattice. The anion in 2a is balanced by a hexakis(acetonitrile)cobalt(III) cation. Additionally, the asymmetric unit of the anion of 2a forms a 1-D polymer bridged by two trifluoroacetate ligands between two adjacent cluster units (b). 2

elements.content: Compound 2b crystallizes with a cobalt countercation coordinated to a pair of tripodal ligands, [Co­{HC­(MeCO)2(MeCNH)}2]3+ (). The O and NH positions of the cation were disordered and refined as a statistical mixture of 2/3 O and 1/3 NH at each site. The H atom was included in calculated positions at 1/3 occupancy on each of these sites. The tripodal ligand is expected to form by coupling of an acetylacetonate ligand bound to cobalt with a molecule of acetonitrile to form β-enaminodione ligands by a mechanism similar previously reported in the synthesis of related compounds from malononitrile (NCCH2CN; ). This process is most likely initiated by removal of an acac ligand from Co­(acac)3 via protonation with trifluoroacetic acid. Similar processes at Co­(acac)3 in the presence of trifluoroacetic acid are known to proceed via radical mechanisms and can lead to a reduction of cobalt, but we believe that the final cation retains the Co3+ oxidation state in this case. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the reaction of Bi­(NO3)3·5H2O with Co­(acac)3 in MeCN produces the same cation with the previously unknown hexanitratobismuth­(III) anion, [Bi­(NO3)6]3– ( and ). In this case, there is no question about the oxidation states of the metals involved since a +2 counterion would require Bi to be +4, which is an unknown oxidation state for that element. The [Bi­(NO3)6]3– has not been previously observed. It possesses noncrystallographic C 2 symmetry with four bidentate and two monodentate nitrate ligands. Additionally, the bond lengths of the cation in both compounds are similar, with the average Co–(N,O) bond distances in 2b and 3 being 1.906(8) and 1.913(6), respectively. Similar coordinating ligands have also been synthesized following the β-enaminodione structure, but bound to metals at only one imino and one carbonyl site, as opposed to the tridentate bonding seen here.

elements.content: Compound 2c was synthesized in a similar fashion using copper­(I) oxide as the metal ion source. This compound also crystallizes as a polymer, with each asymmetric unit bridged by two trifluoroacetate ligands between adjacent units (). Compound 2d was synthesized by applying the same synthetic method with an organic cation. For this reaction, tetramethylammonium hydroxide was added to the solution of BiPh3 and trifluoroacetic acid in acetonitrile ().

elements.content: The formation of these bismuth-oxido cluster compounds tentatively follow a similar formation mechanism as summarized in eq 3. The trifluoroacetic acid added to the solution can displace the weakly bound phenyl ligands in BiPh3 through protonation and benzene elimination. This leads to the formation of a trifluoroacetate species such as Bi­(O2CCF3)3, which can undergo hydrolysis (). It is anticipated that the simple μ-O configuration in (CF3CO2)2Bi-O-Bi­(O2CCF3)2 would be less stable than the μ3-O configuration, which would promote dimerization of these Bi2O fragments. A compound with a Bi2O core is known, but it is stabilized by bulky calixarene ligands. These anions are all charge-balanced by cationic transition metal species. The cations found here are conventional. The cobalt hexakis­(acetonitrile) [Co­(NCMe)6]2+ cation seen in 2a is known to crystallize with small-molecule anions. Other cobalt and nickel cations have been seen to crystallize with large antimony oxo-clusters. The copper­(I) cation [Cu­(NCMe)4]+ in 2c is well-known. The cuprous oxide used in the synthesis of 2c provides an easy way to obtain the Cu+ ion in solution (eq 4). The 19F NMR spectrum of the Bi4O2 clusters showed only one fluorine resonance, indicating that the trifluoroacetate ligands are exchanging on the NMR time scale. No other fluorine-containing compound was observed by NMR in these samples.

elements.content: Several examples of neutral carboxylate-based Bi4O2 cluster compounds have been reported. These include Bi4O2(O2CC6H2F3-3,4,5)8·2­(η6-C6H6), Bi4O2(O2CC6H2F3-3,4,5)8·2­(C6H4Me2-1,4), [Bi4O2(OSiEt3)8] and [Bi4(μ3-O)2(HSal)8]·2solv (solv = MeCN or MeNO2), [Bi4O2{OCH­(CF3)2}8(Et2O)2], [Bi4O2{OCH­(CF3)2}8(THF)], [Bi4O2{OCH­(CF3)2}8(tmeda)2], [Bi4O2{HC8}] (HC8 = (C6H3O)8(CH2)8), [Bi4O2{BnC8}] (BnC8 = [(C6H2O)­(C6H5)]8(CH2)8), and Bi4O2(OAr)4[OC6H3(iPr)­{C­(CH2)2}]2. The Bi4O2 unit is also observed bound in calixarene ligand sets, and these ligands are also known to support a dimerized (Bi4O2)2 species. These compounds can be described as “butterfly-shaped” with the two central Bi atoms being the hinge atoms of the butterfly and the two end Bi atoms as the wingtip atoms. In general for the neutral molecules, the oxide to hinge bismuth distances are longer by 0.1 to 0.2 Å. The difference is smaller in the anionic versions, likely because of the additional ligands attached to the wingtip atoms. Similar to the neutral compounds, the μ3-bridging oxide ligands in these anionic clusters are relatively planar. Three alkoxide-based Bi4O2 clusters have been found to bind additional alkali metal alkoxide units. These include NaBi4O2(OC6F5)9(THF)2, Na2Bi4O2(OC6F5)10(THF)2, and [Li2Bi4O2{2-2-(prop-2-enyl)­phenoxo}10]; those compounds differ in that the bridging oxides interact with the Li+ or Na+ ions and are essentially tetrahedral as a result.

elements.content: Structurally, the carboxylate ligands in the new anionic clusters have a different arrangement than that of the compounds with only eight carboxylates or alkoxides. In 2a–2c, carboxylate ligands bridge the two hinge atoms, which is not seen in 2d or the neutral Bi4O2 carboxylate clusters previously reported. This could be due to the fact that the anionic structures prefer to accommodate additional ligands at the wingtip bismuth atoms, causing some carboxylates to move toward the hinge atoms. In some cases, the additional carboxylates replace coordinated solvent on the Bi4O2 core. The coordination number of the bismuth atoms, however, remains relatively constant, ranging from 5 to 7. A comparison of bond parameters for the newly synthesized clusters as well as neutral carboxylate clusters and oxide clusters is presented in below.

In summary, the reaction of BiPh3 with trifluoroacetic acid and a transition metal ion source leads to the synthesis of anionic bismuth-oxido clusters with transition metal-based countercations. This not only adds to the library of carboxylate bismuth-oxido clusters but also provides insight into a new area of chemistry, as these are some of the first systematically prepared anionic carboxylate clusters. These clusters as well as a Bi4O2 trifluoroacetate cluster with an organic cation were fully characterized using X-ray crystallography and elemental analysis. The anionic Bi4O2 bismuth-oxido clusters contain new bonding patterns not previously observed in neutral carboxylate species, and they should possess different solubilities and stabilities compared to the neutral complexes. These new compounds can be viewed as possible starting materials for further cluster growth toward previously unobserved nuclearities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the reaction of BiPh3 with trifluoroacetic acid and a transition metal ion source leads to the synthesis of anionic bismuth-oxido clusters with transition metal-based countercations. This not only adds to the library of carboxylate bismuth-oxido clusters but also provides insight into a new area of chemistry, as these are some of the first systematically prepared anionic carboxylate clusters. These clusters as well as a Bi4O2 trifluoroacetate cluster with an organic cation were fully characterized using X-ray crystallography and elemental analysis. The anionic Bi4O2 bismuth-oxido clusters contain new bonding patterns not previously observed in neutral carboxylate species, and they should possess different solubilities and stabilities compared to the neutral complexes. These new compounds can be viewed as possible starting materials for further cluster growth toward previously unobserved nuclearities.

elements.content: All reagents and chemicals, unless otherwise stated, were purchased from commercial sources. X-ray crystallography was performed on a Rigaku SCX Mini diffractometer with a Mo radiation source and a graphite monochromator. Structures were solved using the SHELXTL software package. Infrared spectra were taken in the solid state on a PerkinElmer FTIR device. Elemental analyses (C,H,N) were carried out at Galbraith Laboratories.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General

All reagents and chemicals, unless otherwise stated, were purchased from commercial sources. X-ray crystallography was performed on a Rigaku SCX Mini diffractometer with a Mo radiation source and a graphite monochromator. Structures were solved using the SHELXTL software package. Infrared spectra were taken in the solid state on a PerkinElmer FTIR device. Elemental analyses (C,H,N) were carried out at Galbraith Laboratories.

elements.content: Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added. This gave a light yellow solution. Nickel formate (0.146 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the vial was sonicated until most solids had dissolved, giving a green-blue solution. This solution was left to stand for 2 days. After gravity filtration, the solution was left to evaporate slowly. After 2 weeks, cubic colorless crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction developed on the walls of the vial. Yield: 40%. Anal. Found for 1a: C, 11.60; H, 0.63; N, 1.03. Calculated for CoBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95.

Syntheses

Synthesis of [Ni(H2O)4(NCMe)2][Bi6O4(OH)4(CF3CO2)12], 1a 

Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added. This gave a light yellow solution. Nickel formate (0.146 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the vial was sonicated until most solids had dissolved, giving a green-blue solution. This solution was left to stand for 2 days. After gravity filtration, the solution was left to evaporate slowly. After 2 weeks, cubic colorless crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction developed on the walls of the vial. Yield: 40%. Anal. Found for 1a: C, 11.60; H, 0.63; N, 1.03. Calculated for CoBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95.

elements.content: Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added beneath the surface and swirled until uniformly dispersed. This gave a light yellow solution. Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (0.2476 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the solution vial was sonicated for roughly 10 min until all solids had dissolved, giving a deep pink solution. The vial’s cap was opened slightly, and the solution was left to evaporate. After 2 weeks, pink, cubic crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction had formed along the lower walls and base of the vial. These were confirmed by X-ray diffraction to be 1b. Anal. Found for 1b: C, 11.35; H, 0.73; N, 0.90; Calculated for NiBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95. FT-IR (cm–1): 1642­(m,b), 1449­(w), 1190(s), 1153(s), 854­(w), 794­(m), 725(s).

Synthesis of [Co(H2O)4(NCMe)2][Bi6O4(OH)4(CF3CO2)12], 1b 

Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added beneath the surface and swirled until uniformly dispersed. This gave a light yellow solution. Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (0.2476 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the solution vial was sonicated for roughly 10 min until all solids had dissolved, giving a deep pink solution. The vial's cap was opened slightly, and the solution was left to evaporate. After 2 weeks, pink, cubic crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction had formed along the lower walls and base of the vial. These were confirmed by X-ray diffraction to be 1b. Anal. Found for 1b: C, 11.35; H, 0.73; N, 0.90; Calculated for NiBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95. FT-IR (cm-1): 1642(m,b), 1449(w), 1190(s), 1153(s), 854(w), 794(m), 725(s).

elements.content: Triphenylbismuth (0.2213g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of undistilled acetonitrile. Trifluoroacetic acid (0.40 mL, 5.33 mmol) was added, and the solution was mixed gently to again give a pale yellow solution. To this was added 0.0900 g of cobalt­(III) acetylacetonate (0.25 mmol), and the solution was swirled briefly until the metal complex was dissolved. This solution was layered above 6 mL of toluene and was left to stand. After a few days, brownish-pink rectangular prismatic crystals grew on the bottom of the reaction vial, and after a few more days smaller, similarly shaped crystals started to grow on the vial walls as well. These rod-like crystals were found to be 2a. Yield: 54%. Anal. Found for 2a: C, 16.72; H, 1.17; N, 3.29. Calculated for CoBi4C32H18N6O22F30 (%): C, 16.69; H, 0.79; N, 3.65. FT-IR (cm–1): 1644­(s,b), 1444­(m), 1184(s), 1143(s), 856­(w), 794­(m), 725(s).

Triphenylbismuth (0.2213g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of undistilled acetonitrile. These rod-like crystals were found to be 2a. Yield: 54%. Anal. Found for 2a: C, 16.72; H, 1.17; N, 3.29. Calculated for CoBi4C32H18N6O22F30 (%): C, 16.69; H, 0.79; N, 3.65. elements.content: Triphenylbismuth (0.1470 g, 0.34 mmol) and 0.0886 g of cobalt­(III) acetylacetonate (0.25 mmol) were combined in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this was added 6 mL of acetonitrile and 0.225 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (3 mmol). The vial was sonicated until the solids dissolved and then left to evaporate slowly with the cap loosened. About a month later, it was observed that colorless, rectangular prismatic crystals had formed from the thick, brown liquid that remained at the bottom of the vial. These crystals were identified by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystals were washed with diethyl ether. Yield: 30%. Anal. Found for 2b: C, 17.17; H, 1.22; N, 1.23. Calculated for CoBi4C42H28N2O36F42 (%): C, 17.83; H, 1.00; N, 0.99. The analyses suggest that the compound has picked up additional water. Calculated for three additional water molecules, CoBi4C42H34N2O39F42(%): C, 17.49; H, 1.19; N, 0.97. FT-IR (cm–1): 1660­(s,b), 1437­(w), 1263­(w), 1187(s), 1139(s), 1059­(m,b), 1029­(m,b), 850­(w), 794(s), 724(s).

Triphenylbismuth (0.1470 g, 0.34 mmol) and 0.0886 g of cobalt(III) acetylacetonate (0.25 mmol) were combined in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this was added 6 mL of acetonitrile and 0.225 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (3 mmol). The vial was sonicated until the solids dissolved and then left to evaporate slowly with the cap loosened. About a month later, it was observed that colorless, rectangular prismatic crystals had formed from the thick, brown liquid that remained at the bottom of the vial. These crystals were identified by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystals were washed with diethyl ether. Yield: 30%. Anal. Found for 2b: C, 17.17; H, 1.22; N, 1.23. Calculated for CoBi4C42H28N2O36F42 (%): C, 17.83; H, 1.00; N, 0.99. The analyses suggest that the compound has picked up additional water. Calculated for three additional water molecules, CoBi4C42H34N2O39F42(%): C, 17.49; H, 1.19; N, 0.97. FT-IR (cm-1): 1660(s,b), 1437(w), 1263(w), 1187(s), 1139(s), 1059(m,b), 1029(m,b), 850(w), 794(s), 724(s).

elements.content: Triphenylbismuth (0.2204 g, 0.50 mmol) and 0.0702 g of Cu2O (0.49 mmol) were combined in a vial with 4 mL of acetonitrile. This solution was sonicated for several minutes until the solution turned from blue with the purple-red Cu2O solid present to a clear yellow solution with gray solid on the bottom. Trifluoroacetic acid (0.20 mL, 2.7 mmol) was added, and the vial swirled to combine all constituents. The solution was left to evaporate, and yielded large, sheet-like, colorless crystals after 11 days, with a brown, syrupy liquid in the bottom of the vial. These crystals were washed with diethyl ether to remove impurities and were determined to be 2c by single crystal X-ray diffraction.. Yield: 80%. FT-IR (cm–1): 1640­(m,b), 1446­(w), 1190­(m), 1150­(m), 854­(w), 794­(w), 726­(m). Anal. Found for 2c: C, 21.97; H, 1.87; N, 7.11. Calculated for Cu2Bi4C40H26N8OF36 (%): C, 17.91; H, 0.98; N, 4.18. Obtaining elemental analyses for this compound proved problematic because it decomposed under a vacuum, and so samples could not be completely dried. Even though no solvent was found in the crystal lattice, it is possible that disordered MeCN was present, which was indicated by duplicate analyses that were always found to be N-rich. Calculated values including residual 7MeCN gave reasonable agreement (%): C, 21.85; H, 1.60; N, 7.08.

Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added. This gave a light yellow solution. Nickel formate (0.146 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the vial was sonicated until most solids had dissolved, giving a green-blue solution. This solution was left to stand for 2 days. After gravity filtration, the solution was left to evaporate slowly. After 2 weeks, cubic colorless crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction developed on the walls of the vial. Yield: 40%. Anal. Found for 1a: C, 11.60; H, 0.63; N, 1.03. Calculated for CoBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95.

Synthesis of [Co­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>(NCMe)<sub>2</sub>]­[Bi<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>(OH)<sub>4</sub>(CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>12</sub>], <bold>1b</bold>

Triphenylbismuth (0.22 g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of acetonitrile in a 20 mL scintillation vial. To this solution, 0.075 mL of trifluoroacetic acid (1.0 mmol) was added beneath the surface and swirled until uniformly dispersed. This gave a light yellow solution. Cobalt acetate tetrahydrate (0.2476 g, 0.99 mmol) was added, and the solution vial was sonicated for roughly 10 min until all solids had dissolved, giving a deep pink solution. The vial’s cap was opened slightly, and the solution was left to evaporate. After 2 weeks, pink, cubic crystals suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction had formed along the lower walls and base of the vial. These were confirmed by X-ray diffraction to be 1b. Anal. Found for 1b: C, 11.35; H, 0.73; N, 0.90; Calculated for NiBi6C28H19N2O36F36 (%): C, 11.38; H, 0.61; N, 0.95. FT-IR (cm–1): 1642­(m,b), 1449­(w), 1190(s), 1153(s), 854­(w), 794­(m), 725(s).

Synthesis of {[Co­(NCMe)<sub>6</sub>]­[Bi<sub>4</sub>(μ<sub>3</sub>-O)<sub>2</sub>(O<sub>2</sub>CCF<sub>3</sub>)<sub>10</sub>]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>, <bold>2a</bold>

Triphenylbismuth (0.2213g, 0.50 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of undistilled acetonitrile. Trifluoroacetic acid (0.40 mL, 5.33 mmol) was added, and the solution was mixed gently to again give a pale yellow solution. To this was added 0.0900 g of cobalt­(III) acetylacetonate (0.25 mmol), and the solution was swirled briefly until the metal complex was dissolved. This solution was layered above 6 mL of toluene and was left to stand. After a few days, brownish-pink rectangular prismatic crystals grew on the bottom of the reaction vial, and after a few more days smaller, similarly shaped crystals started to grow on the vial walls as well. These rod-like crystals were found to be 2a. Yield: 54%. Anal. Found for 2a: C, 16.72; H, 1.17; N, 3.29. Calculated for CoBi4C32H18N6O22F30 (%): C, 16.69; H, 0.79; N, 3.65. FT-IR (cm–1): 1644­(s,b), 1444­(m), 1184(s), 1143(s), 856­(w), 794­(m), 725(s).
